1.text_: Images of outlandish scenery race through my mind.:<TAP>
\nWhere am I? Why am I here?:<TAP>
\nI can't remember anything.:<TAP>
\nMy memory has abandoned me.:<NONE>
\nI had something I needed to do, right?:<TAP>
\nI definitely had something I needed to do.:
\nI find it difficult to gather my thoughts.\nSuddenly, a voice appears in my consciousness.:<NONE>
"I'm afraid this all comes at a cost. You're going to lose your voice,\nyour senses, your—":<TAP>
\n"Are you certain?":<TAP>

A voice...
That's right. I lost it all.:<TAP>
\nMy will. My speech. My hope. Everything.:
This girl in white...:<TAP>
\nPain constricts my chest. Stirs my empty memory.:<TAP>
\nI know that girl. She was... She was my...:<TAP>
\nArgh, I can't remember! Who am I, anyway!?:
These hands. These legs. This body.:<TAP>
\nAm I...human?:<TAP>
\nNo. I'm not human.:<TAP>
\nI wasn't human.:
\nI got this body when I accomplished my objective.:<NONE>
In this bleak world, I ate the dreams of people\nand desired to become human above all else.:<TAP>
\n...But why is it so damn painful?:
\nI'm finally the human I wished to be, so why?:
"You need to collect more dreams, dear.":<TAP>
\n\nThat voice echoes in my head again.:<TAP>
\nNow that I'm human, why do I have to do this?:<TAP>
\nFragments of memories pierce my heart like thorns.:<NONE>
An impatience I don't understand drives me forward.:<TAP>
\nThe girl in white.:<TAP>
Me, a human.:<TAP>
\nI have to do something.\nOtherwise there's no turning back.:
\nThat's all I know.:<NONE>
I want to be human.:<TAP>
I want to be human.:<TAP>
I want to be human.:<TAP>
\n\nThat should have been my only goal in life.:<TAP>
\nBut now that I've accomplished it, not only am I not happy...:<TAP>
\nI don't even understand these feelings of guilt roiling inside me.:<NONE>
I wander the darkness with no destination.:<TAP>
\nI have no way to tell what happened to my face.:<TAP>
\nBut this slender physique... This fluffy hair...\nThe collar and manacles that clamp down on me...:<TAP>
\nOh, yes. I know exactly who I am.:
The girl in white—:<TAP>
I can't get her out of my head.:<TAP>
\nWho is she? Why do I look like her?\nWhat did I do to her? What did she do to me?:
\nI hear the sound of water splashing in the darkness.:<NONE>
"Hey, Mr. Monster?":<TAP>
\n"When you become human, will you still be my friend?":<TAP>
\n\nI know she said... Yes! She did say something!:
\nMy scattered fragments of memories slowly come together...:<NONE>
How long have I been asleep?:<TAP>
\nI sit up in discomfort and stand on the cold stone floor.:<TAP>
\nI dreamt of the girl over and over again.:<TAP>
\nWhat precious times we spent together.:<NONE>
All my memories came back in my long sleep.:<TAP>
\nOnce again, I stand in The Cage.:<TAP>
\nI need to go back to her as soon as I can;:<TAP>
\nI need to give back what I have stolen.:<NONE>
"Well! Look who's finally up.":<TAP>

An odd object floats up and speaks to me,
pretending it has no idea what's happening.:<TAP>
\nI can't imagine anything more audacious,\nbut I will have to rely on the thing for now.:<TAP>
\nI've lost so much—so much—\nbut at least I have my memories.:
I retrace my steps through The Cage in order to save her.:<TAP>

Once she's back to normal, I will reply to the question
I had left unanswered.:<TAP>
\nAnd I will say...:<TAP>
\n\nYes. I will be your friend.:
This is where I play::<TAP>
\nAn old ruin a little ways from my house.:<TAP>
\nIt's my special place, and I don't wanna tell anyone about it.:<NONE>
I always come here when I want to be alone.:<TAP>
\nBut one day, there was someone else here, \nwhich had never happened before.:<TAP>
\nIt was an older girl reading a book in the shade—I remember\nshe looked kinda sad.:<NONE>
I could tell right away she was a Noble::<TAP>
\nHer clothes were beautiful...:<TAP>
\nAnd she was the prettiest person I'd ever seen in my life!:<TAP>
\nAfter a second, she saw me staring and gave me a weird smile.:<NONE>
"You want this book?" she asked me.:<TAP>
\n\n"I'm done with it.":<TAP>
\nI took it from her, but I was really nervous the whole time;\nI'd never actually talked to a Noble before!:<NONE>
The book she gave me was a collection of children's stories.:<TAP>
\nIt had tons of pretty pictures,:<TAP>
\nand I've read it every single day since.:<NONE>
Each story was about a princess who fell in love with a prince.:<TAP>
\nIt was so different from my own life, and it helped me forget\nhow sad everything was for me, if just for a little while.:<NONE>
But the book was also weird::<TAP>

All the pictures of the princesses had been scratched over 
with black ink...:<TAP>
\nAnd the last page of every story was torn out.:<NONE>
While I was certain all the princesses would live happily\never after...:<TAP>
\nI also wanted to know how the stories ended,:<TAP>
\nwhich meant I needed to find the Noble girl.:<NONE>
Eventually, I decided to go into town and look for her.:<TAP>
\nIt's not just that I wanted to know how the stories ended—\nI also wanted to see her again.:<TAP>
\nBecause even though I knew we were worlds apart,:<TAP>
\n\nI still thought I might be able to be her friend.:<NONE>
There was a lively wedding taking place in town that day.:<TAP>
\nAnd while the pretty bride in her white dress was surrounded\nby crowds of people, she looked so very lonely.:<NONE>
I recognized the bride right away.:<TAP>
\nIt was the Noble girl.:<TAP>

Part of me wanted to run up and congratulate her,
but I hesitated.:<NONE>
Because even though everyone around her was smiling big,:<TAP>
\nshe looked like...:<TAP>
\n\nshe was screaming on the inside.:<NONE>
I had a dream.:<TAP>

In it, the Noble girl in her white dress
was trying to tell me something.:<NONE>
"Don't lose ■■ ■■," she said.:<TAP>

As she talked, red started to spread out from her chest, 
staining her nice white dress.:<TAP>
\nThe color was far too sad for the nice Noble girl,\nand I woke up from the dream in a panic.:<NONE>
I went back to playing alone in the ruins.:<TAP>

But one day, I noticed something stuck between 
a couple of stones.:<TAP>
\nIt was one of the missing story endings.:<TAP>
\nIt showed the prince and princess at their happy wedding.:<NONE>
Later, I started hearing rumors in town::<TAP>
\nDidja hear that Noble lady ran away barefoot?:
\nDidja hear she was cackling madly?:
\n\nDidja hear she killed herself?:

But I know they're not talking about the nice Noble girl,
because all princesses get to live happily ever after.:<NONE>
"How do you fare, My Prince?":<TAP>
\nHe asks about my condition as we walk through the forest\ntoward the wasteland.:<NONE>
"Well enough," I say as I glance in his direction.:<TAP>
\n"But shouldn't you stop and conduct some maintenance?:<TAP>
\nThis forest air can't be good for clockwork bodies like yours.":<NONE>
"All is in good order, My Prince. Do not trouble yourself.":<TAP>
\nI know he only says this because he worries about my illness.:<TAP>
\nI stop our progress for a moment and turn to him.:<NONE>
"And what if a fight finds us? We should check to be sure.":<TAP>
\nHe nods slowly before taking a seat.:<TAP>
\nThen he powers down, causing the eyes behind his\nbandages to go dark.:<NONE>
It's so much easier to start a war than stop one.:<TAP>

Once the fighting starts, violence leads to distrust,
creating a vicious circle where peace seems impossible.:<NONE>
This is why we are currently traveling from country to country:\nTo create a third power which might mediate negotiations\nand find a way to lead us out of this bloody war.:<NONE>
But my status and bloodline mean there are many who wish me ill.:<TAP>
\nThankfully, my companion has saved my life time and again.:<NONE>
He is a clockwork man, and there is little I can offer him.:<TAP>
\nThe best I can do is assist in his maintenance.:<NONE>
I feel a tightness in my chest.<WAIT=010>\nMy body grows heavy.:<TAP>
\nSweat slicks my hair against my head.:<NONE>
\nIt's clear my illness plans to claim me one way or the other.:<TAP>
\nStifling a cough, I retrieve a bottle from an inner pocket.:<NONE>
I snap off the seal and drink it down.:<TAP>
\nIt is the last of the medicine that holds my illness at bay.:<TAP>
\nOnce it wears off, I will know how bad my condition truly is.:<NONE>
My breathing steadies.:<TAP>
\nIt is but a temporary reprieve, but it will do.:<TAP>
\n\nMaintenance is almost finished.:<NONE>
I return the empty bottle to the same pocket I took it from\nand wait for my guardian to wake up.:<TAP>
\nHe won't worry now—at least for a while.:<TAP>
\nThe medicine will see to that.:<NONE>
I can't afford to show him my true pain.:<TAP>
\nAnd besides, it's not like I'm going to get better.:<TAP>
\n\nSuddenly, my companion wakes with a whirr.:<NONE>
"I'm operating well," he says. "Thank you.":<TAP>
\n"Glad to hear it," I reply softly. "Let's keep going.":<TAP>
\n\n"Yes, My Prince.":<NONE>
We have no time to waste and no time to stop.:<TAP>
\nThat is why I decided to continue with the lie.:<TAP>
\nIt's the right thing to do—I know it is.:<NONE>
I am on a journey of revenge.:<TAP>
\nThe kingdom razed my home, killed my sister,\nand took everything from me.:<TAP>

But its lust for power fed an unsustainable hunger for war, 
and it eventually collapsed.:<TAP>
\nStill, scattered remnants of its forces remain.:<TAP>
\n\nAnd I won't stop until every last one of them is dead.:<NONE>
I tarry for a while in a small village.:<TAP>
\nUnder the midday sun, I hear a voice call for help.:<TAP>
\nI see a kingdom soldier raise a fist \nand bring it down on the head of a woman.:<TAP>
\nHe moves to deliver a second blow.:<TAP>
\nI leap in the way and take it myself before swiftly ending his life.:<NONE>
The woman begins thanking me profusely...:<TAP>
\nBut I ignore her.:<TAP>
I fight for revenge—not to save lives or spread justice.:<TAP>
\n\nAs I move to leave, the woman bars my path.:<TAP>
\nAsking to see my prosthetic arm, she draws in close.:<NONE>
She examines it carefully, looking it up and down.:<TAP>
\nIt was damaged when I took the blow\nthe soldier intended for her.:<TAP>
\nThough I try to explain that I can repair my arm,:<TAP>
\nshe waves me off with a dismissive grunt.:<TAP>

"We've a skilled engineer in the village," she says.
"Come along.":<TAP>
\nBefore I can think to protest further,\nshe takes my hand in hers and leads me off.:<NONE>
I am guided to an engineer so that my arm might be repaired.:<TAP>
\nThe engineer is indeed skilled, but lacks the needed parts for repairs—\nand unfortunately, it will be some time before they're available.:<TAP>
\nStill determined to show her thanks, the woman huffs loudly,\ngrabs my good arm, and drags me off anew.:<NONE>
We end up in the village pub.:<TAP>
\nShe gathers the drinkers around her and spins an epic tale\nof how I saved her from the kingdom brigand.:<TAP>
\n\nSoon, I find myself regaled with food, drink, and song from all corners.:<NONE>
I take a bite of something and nearly swoon;:<TAP>
\nI can't remember the last time I enjoyed a hot meal.:<TAP>
\n\nWhen the woman leans in and asks how it tastes,:<TAP>
\n\nI feel an unfamiliar smile slowly make its way across my lips.:<NONE>
How long has it been since I smiled? Weeks? Years? More?:<TAP>
\nI thought I'd lost the ability to do such a thing long ago.:<NONE>
Eventually, the parts arrive and my arm is finally repaired.:<TAP>

The woman asks me how it feels, and I'm both surprised and
delighted that it seems to move more smoothly than before.:<TAP>
\nAs I test it out, the engineer smiles at me and says,:<TAP>
\n\n"Consider this my way of saying thanks for saving my wife.":<NONE>
It turns out the engineer and the woman are married.:<TAP>
\nShe turns red as he talks about everything he loves about her.:<TAP>
\nI can only chuckle and show a wry smile as I listen.:<NONE>
\nFinally, she can take no more attention and leads me out of the shop.:<TAP>
\nAs we walk, she tells me they have been married almost three years.:<TAP>
\nShe also thanks me again for my actions from before.:<NONE>
This time, I manage to face the woman and thank her\nfor the assistance.:<TAP>
\nI tell her my work in the village is done and I will be on\nmy way...:<TAP>
\n...But that's not the entire truth.:<TAP>
\nI'm also afraid of what might happen if I grow used\nto the warmth and kindness of others.:<NONE>
The villagers all gather at the edge of town to see me off.:<TAP>
\n"Come see us again real soon!" says the woman.:<TAP>

As I walk away, the last thing I see is her small hand
happily waving goodbye.:<NONE>
It wasn't long after leaving the village that I heard the news::<TAP>
\nA soldier was attacking the village in revenge.:<TAP>
\nBefore I even know it, I am on my feet and running like the\nvery wind itself.:<NONE>
I find the village in flames.:<TAP>

The soldier is roaming about madly as he scours 
the village in search of every last person he can find.:<TAP>

"That man was family!" he cries as he puts another
house to the torch.:<TAP>
\n"All of you will pay for his death with your lives!":<TAP>
\nMy vision is fire.:<NONE>
Before I even have the chance to feel my building rage,\nI engage the man in battle.:<TAP>
\nMy arm works even better than before.:<TAP>
\nIn a moment, I cut him down like a dog.:<NONE>
When the deed is done, I walk around the village in search of\nsurvivors.:<TAP>
\nIn the very last house, I find the woman and the engineer with\ntheir arms wrapped around each other and their bodies still.:<TAP>
\nI thought I had saved them—saved all of them—from\na terrible fate that first night...:
\nBut my actions had only been the impetus for an even greater tragedy.:<NONE>
These innocent people had been caught in the cycle of revenge,\nand now their lifeless eyes stare accusingly up at me.:<TAP>
\nYour power did this. Your hate. Your thirst for retribution.:
\nAnd you know what? They're right. I did this. It is all because of me.:
As I fight, I only add more links to the chain of revenge—but if I stop,\nthe remaining soldiers will continue to commit their horrid atrocities.:<TAP>
\nSo I have to fight.:<TAP>
\nI have no choice.:<TAP>
\nBut in so doing, will I, too, become an object of\nhatred in this <size=40>world of neverending slaughter</size>?:<TAP>
\nAll that lays before my eyes is a <size=40>crimson world of blood and fire</size>.:<NONE>
Wind rustles in the trees.:<TAP>
\nCrows caw softly in the gloaming.:<TAP>

As I scan the quiet forest in search of any possible threat,
the prince at my side murmurs, "It's so peaceful here.":<NONE>
He is here in search of a way to lead our country out of war.:<TAP>

And as he travels from nation to nation preaching his message
of peace, I walk at his side to protect him from those who
refuse to listen.:<NONE>

But I am a clockwork man created for war, and no matter
how much time we spend together, the truth of his message
continues to elude me.:<NONE>
I draw close to the prince as he contemplates the setting sun.:<TAP>
\nI wonder why he would think this place to be "peaceful.":<TAP>
\nPerhaps it has something to do with the red hues of dusk?:<NONE>
\n\nAs the prince's disease worsened, so did grow his impatience.:<TAP>
\n\nIt would seem he desires to achieve peace as quickly as possible.:<TAP>
\n\nSo when I suggest we rest in a church until he feels better,:<TAP>
\nit takes a good deal of effort to get him to agree.:<NONE>
Today again, the prince's condition is poor, \nso we wait for nightfall in the church.:<TAP>
\nI take this opportunity to ask him:\n“What is a peaceful world?”:<TAP>
\nHe looks at me with surprise,\nbut a willful flame burns in his eyes.:<NONE>
After a moment, a thin smile crosses his lips.:<TAP>
\nHe reaches out, puts a hand on my chest, and says,:<TAP>
\n\n"It means you never have to hurt here.":
It must be a different sort of pain from wounds as I know them.:<TAP>
\nHe does not notice my lack of understanding and continues to talk.:<TAP>
\n\nI simply nod my head,:<TAP>
\nhoping it will bring him energy.:<NONE>
\nThe disease spreads. The prince's body withers and fades.:<TAP>
\nWhen he can no longer stand, I travel alone to nearby villages\nin search of any food or medicine they can spare.:<NONE>
In the villages, I see people driven mad by the horrors of war.:<TAP>
\nThey grieve for lost family. \nThey curse their empty bellies.:<TAP>
\nAnd they all turn their weapons on me—\nthe clockwork man.:<NONE>
One day, I find a single apple in the woods.:<TAP>

My prince lacks the strength to eat it on his own, 
so I chew small bites and feed it to him as a mother
bird would its own young.:<NONE>
As I see his haggard cheeks and hear his final,\ngasping breath...:<TAP>

I feel a pain deep within my chest and finally realize the
truth of everything that my prince has been fighting for.:<TAP>
It means you never have to hurt here, he had said.:
\nOh, but why did it take such loss for me to finally understand?:<NONE>
My bODy is RAvaGeD bY RuSt.:<TAP>
\nmY meMOrIes GrOw DeFEcTIve.:<TAP>
\nYEt I stAy by hIS SIdE: MY PriNCe, wHo TImE eROdED.:<NONE>
THerE is A gAPinG, EmpTY hOLE iN mY cHEst.:<TAP>
\nThE pAiN I feLT jUSt BeFOrE hE DieD...:<TAP>
\niS GOnE.:<NONE>
I wILL PAinT tHIS ChurCH ReD.:<TAP>
\nI wILL uSE THe BloOd OF HUmANs WHo DEniED HiS SalVATioN\nANd nOW InTRuDE oN hIS SLuMBeR.:<NONE>
\nIN ACcORDaNCE WiTH thE PROMiSE We MAdE ThAT Day,:<TAP>
\nI WiLL CONTInuE to ProTECt HIm...:<TAP>
\naNd ThE <size=40>PEaCE</size> he dESiRed FOReVER...:<NONE>
Red spikes top the walls that surround my family's manor.:<TAP>

They stand there proudly as they stretch up to the sky,
and the color reminds all who pass of blood.:<NONE>
But these spikes are not there to keep intruders at bay;:<TAP>
\nour family has no need of such defenses.:<NONE>
None ever approach our house, \nwhich is known as The Demon's Den.:<TAP>

And if some foolhardy brigand ever did so dare, 
he would soon learn that a death on the spikes is much, 
much sweeter than what awaits behind our doors.:<NONE>
No, the spikes are not meant to keep people out;:<TAP>
\nthey are there to keep the demons in.:<NONE>
Our training is harsh. Our work cruel. \nOur teachings inhumane.:<TAP>
\nOne might expect that there would be those who\nare unable to stand it, and scheme to escape.:<TAP>

And in fact, there have been a few brave souls
who attempted to cross the wall.:<NONE>
But every single one of them was killed;:<TAP>
\n\nthe crimson spikes serve to remind us of this fact.:<NONE>
I personally knew one man who plotted escape.:<TAP>
\nHe was the elder brother of the lord in power—my uncle.:<NONE>
My uncle objected to an assassination demanded of him.:<TAP>
\nBut when he tried to flee, he met the same fate as those who\ndid so before him: his head put on display for all to see.:<NONE>
\nMy family's teachings are impossibly strict—\nand as the daughter of the lord, I was not exempt.:<TAP>
\nIf anything, my teachings were even more severe.:<TAP>
\nIt was only natural given my standing.:<NONE>
\nThere are no smiles in a house of assassins; we are\nshowered with naught but shouting and demands.:<TAP>
\nMy uncle, however, always had time to spare a grin for me.:<TAP>
\n\nHe was the only one who ever did.:<NONE>
But on that grim day, his smile vanished.:<TAP>

His younger brother cut him down to set an example, 
and his face would forevermore be frozen in a rictus of pain.:<NONE>
I learned many hard truths on that day::<TAP>
\nI would never cross the spikes. Kindness has no meaning.:<TAP>
\n\nMy life is nothing but orders and blood.:<NONE>
Time passed and I took over the household from my father.:<TAP>
\nNow, I am able to freely come and go as I please.:<TAP>
\nYet somehow, I remain an assassin.:<NONE>
A thought came to me just now::<TAP>
\n\nDo I blame the spikes for my murderous ways?:<NONE>

Am I a bloodthirsty ghoul who uses my job and those spikes
as an excuse to kill? Do I willingly return because it is the
only place where I will ever find acceptance?:<NONE>
As I look up from outside the wall, \nthe familiar sky stings my eyes.:<TAP>
\nDid I...make a <size=40>mistake</size> somewhere?:<TAP>

The same questions roll ever onward in my mind—yet all I
can do is surrender myself to my own dark thoughts.:<NONE>
My life's mission is to explore the entire world,:<TAP>
\nfor only <size=40>great hardships</size> can make me feel alive.:<TAP>
\nEverything besides adventuring is merely a footnote.:<TAP>
\nI wager I'll feel this way until the day I die.:<NONE>
I've faced the challenge of many unexplored regions in my life::<TAP>
\nMountains untrodden by man, scorched deserts, frozen islands, \npitch-black forests, caves that lead to an endless abyss...:<TAP>
\nSo many adventures I can't even remember them all.:<NONE>
Just the other day, my wife and I learned that our long-awaited\nfirst child was in her belly!:<TAP>
\nOf course, I wanted to help however I could.:<TAP>
\nWhich is why I left our snug house in the snowy mountains\nand began the long climb down.:<NONE>
My destination is a small nearby town.:<TAP>
\nHow long has it been since I've made this trip?:<TAP>
\nMy wife is usually the one who does the shopping.:<TAP>
\nIn any case, I don't mind doing what I must to help out\nduring this time.:<NONE>

I haven't tasted the bustle of civilization in a long while,
but I pay it little mind as I search for the shops my wife
told me about.:<TAP>
\nHeh. It's funny how quickly I get turned around in the streets—:<TAP>
\nif only I was navigating a mountain path instead!:<NONE>
As I wander about, a merchant calls me over.:<TAP>
\nHe recognizes me as a renowned adventurer, \nand he says he has items he wants me to look at.:<TAP>
\nHe has a keen eye, this shopkeeper! Ha ha ha!:<NONE>
\nThe shopkeep lays out several items across his display::<TAP>
\nflint to create bonfires, a talisman that wards off illness,\nand ice that never melts, even under the hottest of suns.:<TAP>
\nAll extremely useful items on any adventure!:<NONE>
He claims these items are all in high demand, \nso I buy them on the spot.:<TAP>
\nLady luck is really smiling on me today!:<NONE>
The moment I leave the stall, reality smacks me in the face::<TAP>
\nI spent all our money and didn't get a thing my wife wanted!:<TAP>
\nAh, well. Nothing to be done about it now.:<NONE>
So I sell my coat and use the money to buy what I came for.:<TAP>
\nNot the smartest thing to go coatless in the dead of winter,\nbut I'm hearty—I'll find a way to survive.:<TAP>

Mine is a body forged in the fires of countless journeys.
It'd take more than this to do me in!:<NONE>
As I make my way back up the mountain,:<TAP>
\na blizzard suddenly comes upon me.:<TAP>
\nI'm cold—really cold—but I spy a nearby\nrocky shelter and decide to hunker down.:
As I settle in, I try to start a bonfire with my new flint.:<TAP>
\nBut the moment I strike it, the damn thing shatters into pieces.:<TAP>
It's a dud—talk about unlucky.:<NONE>
\nSomehow, I manage to make it home through the wind and snow.:<TAP>
\nWhen my wife sees me, she demands to know \nwhy I was wandering around without my coat on,:<TAP>
\nso I tell her the whole crazy story.:<TAP>
\n\nStill, I'm pretty excited about my two remaining treasures!:<NONE>
That night, I am plagued by a high fever.:<TAP>
You expect this kind of thing when you walk around in a blizzard without a coat, but it means my talisman that wards off illness is also a bust!:
\nAnother dud! Can you believe it?:<NONE>
Trying to kill the fever dead, I put my never-melt ice in a sack\nand set it on my forehead.:<TAP>
\nI bet you can guess how this goes...:<NONE>
I take the bag of lukewarm water off my head and toss it\naside in disgust.:<TAP>
\n\nThat damn shopkeep took me for all I had!:<TAP>
\nStill, it's not all a loss; I live on a snowy mountain...:<TAP>
\nSo if it's ice I need, I just have to walk outside!\nHa ha ha ha ha!:<NONE>
The wife's in a terrible mood...:<TAP>
\nIt's because I forgot her birthday which, yeah, was a mistake.:<TAP>
\n\nBut does she need to be this angry?:
\nShe's not being reasonable—and I'm going to tell her so!:<NONE>
\nUh oh. The moment I open my mouth, she launches into a rant\nabout all of her woes::<TAP>
\nI don't understand women. I'm crude. I'm insensitive.:<TAP>
\nShe starts unloading all sorts of stuff on me. Blah blah blah.:<TAP>
Well, I'm sure as hell not going to just lie back and take all that!:<NONE>
"You know, this is what I hate about you!" I snarl.:<TAP>
\n"You're always bringing up these stupid unrelated issues!":<TAP>

The moment the words leave my mouth, I know I've gone too far;
one look at her face is all I need to realize that.:<NONE>
\nShe points to the door—and I know what that means.:
\nAnd while part of me is annoyed as hell at all of this...:<TAP>
\nI decide to get out while the getting's good.:<NONE>
I escape to the mess hall.:<TAP>
\nMy friends come up to me and ask what's the matter—\nguess I look a little pale.:<TAP>
\nBut when I tell them how I just had a blow-up with the wife, \ntheir concern dissolves into peals of laughter.:<NONE>
After they have their fun, they tell me I'm the one at fault.:<TAP>
\nEach one has a different strategy I can use to make amends.:<TAP>
\nAs they talk, I realize they're pretty good pals, all in all.:<TAP>
\n\nI decide to put their plan into motion.:<NONE>
I return to the room and pick my wife up off her feet.:<TAP>
\nShe seems perplexed, but intrigued—which is good.:<TAP>

I then start spinning her around the room in a dance,
showing off my strength as well as my moves.:<NONE>
\nBut of course, I take it too far.:<TAP>
\nBy the time I realize it, her face has progressed from confusion\nto downright fury.:<TAP>
\n\nSo before I can wreck it more, I dash out of the room.:<NONE>
As I think about what to do, the unit commander appears.:<TAP>
\nWord of our marital squabble has spread throughout the base.:<TAP>
\nHe warns me it will be a hindrance to our operations.:<NONE>
Since he seems to care, I tell him what happened and ask for\nhis advice.:<TAP>
\nHe chuckles a little.:<TAP>
\nHe then tells me he doesn't have any ideas—\nand doesn't care enough to think of any.:<NONE>
But then he gives me a piece of "paper"—something people\napparently used long, long ago in order to make amends.:<TAP>
\nI don't know what he's thinking, but he's not the kind of man\nto act without purpose.:<TAP>
\nI decide his words must have some meaning.:
Apparently "paper" is a relic of the past used for writing.:<TAP>
\nThat's when it comes to me::<TAP>
\n\nSince I usually say too much, I'll write a "letter" to my wife instead.:<NONE>
But I'm not sure what usually goes into a letter.:<TAP>
\nMaybe I should start with thanks for everything she does\nfor me every day?:<TAP>
\nNo, wait. An apology is probably better.:<NONE>
I write letter after letter as I think of my wife.:<TAP>
\nI write, then erase. Write, then erase.:<TAP>
\nWrite, then erase. After ten or so attempts, \nthe letter is finally complete.:<NONE>
I go home and hand it to my wife, whose eyes go wide.:<TAP>
\nThis could just be because a letter is so unfamiliar,\nbut more likely it's because I'm genuinely apologizing.:<NONE>
Once she reads the letter, she smiles and looks at me.:<TAP>
\nThen she wraps me up in a hug...:<TAP>
\nIt would seem all is forgiven.:<NONE>
My messy writing on the crumpled paper was simple::<TAP>
\n"I will protect and love you with all of my life.:<TAP>
\n\nThis I <size=40>swear</size>...":<TAP>
\n\nNo matter what the future may hold.:<NONE>
I think back on the past.:<TAP>
\nOn memories of the boy who will never come home.:<TAP>
\nAnd on the happy family in the photo.:<NONE>
My husband embraces me.:<TAP>
\nHis <size=40>warmth</size> is the only constant in my life, and as he holds me, \nmy chilly heart slowly melts.:<TAP>
\nI never want to lose him, I think.:
\n\nNever.:
\nA deafening rumble suddenly reverberates throughout the base,\nalong with a siren.:<TAP>
\nThe announcement that follows tells us what we never\nwanted to hear::<TAP>
\nFlowers have invaded the base itself for the very first time.:<NONE>
Cradling the photo, my husband and I dash for the exit.:<TAP>
\nIt would be folly to fight the Flowers unarmed,\nso we decide to evacuate instead.:<NONE>
The base is already a stage of tragedy.:<TAP>
\nOur fellow prisoners, unable to fight the sudden army of Flowers, \nhave been decimated.:<NONE>
Among the bodies, we hear a voice calling for help.:<TAP>
\nBut we know that stopping means death.:<TAP>
\nSo we run...and don't look back.:<TAP>
\n\nAs we do, we offer a silent apology.:<NONE>
We run for our lives, but the Flowers are everywhere.:<TAP>
\nEventually, they corner us and launch their assault.:<TAP>
\nThis is it, I think—\nbut the expected pain never comes.:
\nInstead, my husband leaps in front of me \nand takes the attack in my place.:<NONE>
Somehow, he is still alive—but he will not survive another strike.:<TAP>
\nHe screams at me to run, but instead, I grip the photo\nand step forward.:<TAP>
\nOur child will protect us, my darling.:
\nAnd if not, at least I will die at your side.:
Just as the Flower's next attack is about to land,\narmed prisoners appear with our commander and cut it down.:<TAP>
\nThe defense operation has been put in motion—:<TAP>
\n\nand somehow, the two of us are still alive.:<NONE>
My husband's wounds look painful, but he just chuckles and says\nhe's proud to have such badges of honor.:<TAP>
\nI'm relieved to see he's in good enough shape to joke.:<NONE>
The two of us retreat with the commander.:<TAP>
\nMy husband's wounds are deep and he is taken to the infirmary for surgery.:<TAP>
\nI pray fervently that he will make a full recovery.:<NONE>
I hand the photo to my husband as a good-luck charm.:<TAP>
\nOur boy is looking down on you; everything will be all right.:
\nMy husband clutches it to his chest as they wheel him away.:<NONE>
My heart grows cold. How much time has passed since he went in?:<TAP>
\nHe'd been joking around, so surely he's going to be okay.:<TAP>
\nBut what if...?:
\n\nI feel like the uncertainty will crush me under its weight.:<NONE>
Finally, my husband emerges from the infirmary.:<TAP>
\n\nSeeing him safe, I let out a small gasp of relief.:<TAP>
\nHowever, he has no memory of the recent past...:<TAP>
\nand the photo has also disappeared.:<NONE>
The memory loss is due to shock, and only temporary—:<TAP>
\nbut no one can explain where the photo went.:<TAP>

My husband, as if sensing my unease, wraps me up in
another tight embrace.:<NONE>
As I feel his <size=40> warmth</size>, my concerns melt away once more.:<TAP>
\nSo long as you are safe, that's all that matters.:
\nIt is the only thing that matters...:
I inhale a lungful of battlefield air, rich with a mix of\ngunsmoke and blood.:<TAP>

Our operation was a smashing success, but while my fellow
soldiers are content going back to base and celebrating our victory,
I'm heading out on a new mission.:<TAP>
\nBecause the only time I feel alive now is when I fight.:<NONE>
Revenge drove me. It's all that ever drove me.:<TAP>
\nBut then I ended up killing my own father.:<TAP>
\nAnd on top of that, it turns out the people I called my family\nwere actually my enemies.:<TAP>
\nWhat a goddamn joke, right? Anybody else laughing here?:<NONE>
When I return to reality, I see piles of corpses everywhere.:<TAP>
\nIt's all my doing, this carnage, but instead of rage or sorrow,\nI just feel a strange sense of calm.:<TAP>
\nHonestly, killing is the only thing that brings me peace anymore.:<NONE>
Suddenly, an explosion shakes the ground—a close one.:<TAP>
\nThe sky turns red as flames arc up toward the heavens.:<TAP>
\nAs I stare at this crimson sky, my heart begins to race.:<TAP>
\nI set out in search of someone to fight, hoping to calm my jangled nerves.:<NONE>
The war has turned in our favor.:<TAP>
\nThe enemies we don't kill we send running into the night...:<TAP>
\nBut it still isn't enough.:<TAP>
\nI find myself picking my way across a viscera-strewn battlefield\njust in case we missed a straggler.:<NONE>
After a bit, I sense someone hiding behind a collapsed house.:<TAP>
\nBattle fever floods my senses.:<TAP>
\nI raise my sword and leap out of hiding, prepared to strike down my terrible foe.:<TAP>
\nBut there, crouching on the ground, is a little girl.:<NONE>
Goddammit, I think.:
We're under orders to protect civilians, which means I gotta \ndrag this kid around with me until I find a place to dump her off. :
\nWhat a pain in the ass.:
\nI extend a bloody hand and grab the girl by the arm.:<NONE>
She screams. I don't care.:<TAP>
\nI give her a good yank and start walking.:<TAP>
\nShe responds by pinwheeling her other arm and toppling\nface-down into the mud.:<TAP>
\n\nThat's when I realize the kid is blind.:<NONE>
The girl, still sitting on the ground, grabs my hand and says,:<TAP>
\n\n"Oh no, mister! You're bleeding. Are you okay?":<TAP>
\n\nThe question hits me wrong, and I smack her hand away.:<TAP>
\nAfter that, we wait in a long, uncomfortable silence.:<NONE>
"It's not my blood," I say finally,:<TAP>
\n\nas much to break the silence as anything else.:<TAP>

I wipe my hand on my pants to clear off as much gore as I can, 
then help the kid up.:<NONE>
Her hands are so damn soft.:
\nI'd forgotten hands could be soft.:<TAP>
\nThe only thing mine are good for any more is murder;\nit's hard to believe her hands and mine are the same thing.:<NONE>
With no other choice, I throw her across my back and start\nworking my way back to base.:<TAP>
\nI can feel the kid's warmth against me.:<TAP>
\nAnd there, in the strange silence you always get on a\nbattlefield after a fight...:<TAP>
\nThe only thing I can hear is the beating of my own heart.:<NONE>
Eventually, we make it to a field hospital.:<TAP>
\nIt's a nice place, actually, with sunlight coming through the\nwindows and wind rustling the trees.:<TAP>
\nThe kid seems okay with it, at least.:<TAP>
\nShe lies on a bed, her gaze trained on the window to her side.:<NONE>
"Hey, kid," I ask her.:<TAP>
\n"What were you doing on the ground back there?":<TAP>
\nShe pauses for a second, then speaks.:<TAP>
\nShe tells me how she'd been neglected by her parents her whole life\nbefore they finally abandoned her once the war came home.:<NONE>
When her story is done, she turns her head in my direction\nand asks::<TAP>
\n\n"What color is the sky right now, mister?":<TAP>
\n\nI take a look out the window.:<TAP>
\n"Blue," I say.:<TAP>
\n"A nice, deep blue.":<TAP>
\nShe closes her eyes—I have no idea why—and begins to try and\nimagine what blue might look like.:
I don't know why I feel uneasy here, but I do.:<TAP>
\nSomething about being near this kid puts me on edge.:<TAP>
\nMy heart is racing again—but in a different way\nthan the discomfort I've felt for my entire life.:<TAP>
\nAnd as I try to identify what this strange feeling is,\nI picture the <size=40>color of the sky</size> in the girl's imagination.:<NONE>
"What should I do...?":<TAP>

I sit in the briefing room, continuing to turn the problem
over and over in my mind.:<TAP>

I've been up all night thinking about it
and am now beyond exhausted.:<NONE>
See, I have to write a telegram to my family back home,:<TAP>
\nbut I can't think of a single thing to say.:<NONE>

My squad came back victorious from battle a few days ago,
at which point everyone sat down and wrote their parents
just like always.:<TAP>
\n\nI joined the army eight years ago...:<TAP>
\nAnd I haven't contacted my family a single time.:<NONE>
It would be strange to send them something now. Crazy.:<TAP>

And every time I think back on my time with them,
I come up with more excuses not to do it.:<NONE>
My fellow soldiers are loud and boisterous, like always.:<TAP>
\nI begin to wonder what kinds of messages they send.:<TAP>
\nI sit still and listen in, hoping it will give me a better idea\nof what to write.:<NONE>
One man says he sent his parents a telegram about being\npromoted to captain.:<TAP>

It's not true—he made it up—but his parents love hearing 
stories about how successful he is, so he figures it's okay 
to stretch the truth a little.:<NONE>
Another man's telegrams always focus on memories he \nand his parents made together.:<TAP>

Today's letter is all about how they used to play ball with
each other; he claims it will distract them from how lonely
they are now that he's gone.:<NONE>

Everyone speaks so cheerfully about the thought they put into
telegrams home.:<TAP>
\nAnd though they are my comrades—and my friends—:<TAP>
\n\nI can't help but feel the gulf between our lives.:<TAP>
\nThe worlds we grew up in were too different.:<NONE>
Here's the thing: Ours is a country that values military might\nabove all else, but my parents?:<TAP>
\nThey're both anti-war activists.:<TAP>
\nNeedless to say, their beliefs earned me more than my share\nof dirty looks and unkind whispers when I was a kid.:<NONE>
One day, the army shot and killed my father. \nWhat a joke, right?:<TAP>
\nHe's spent his entire life preaching peace, then died without\naccomplishing a single damn thing.:<TAP>
I took a lesson from that: Give your life some meaning. Make it matter.:
Later, I decided to join the army and climb the ranks—but when\nI told Mom about my plan, she said I was insane.:<TAP>
\nThe moment she spoke those words, \nI knew I had to get out of that house.:<TAP>
\nSo I slammed the door and stormed off, then spent years trying\nand failing to forget the empty look in her eyes as I departed.:<NONE>
In an ironic twist, I never did climb the ladder the way I\nswore I would.:<TAP>

But today, after eight years spent trying to bury every last
memory of my family, I finally figure out the telegram I want
to send::<TAP>
\n\nIt's an apology.:<TAP>
\nFor everything.:<NONE>
I'm nervous after I send the telegram. What if she doesn't respond?:<TAP>
\nHell, what if she disowns me? I couldn't blame her for that.:<TAP>
But before I can think too hard about it, I get her response: Honey, I'm just so glad you're alive.:
Why was my father an anti-war activist, anyway?:<TAP>
\nWhy did my joining the army weigh so heavily on my mother?:<TAP>

I don't have a clue, because I've spent my whole life
actively avoiding a search for those answers.:<NONE>
The mistakes I made in the past will never go away.:<TAP>

But as I think of my military companions and their families,
another thought comes to me::<NONE>
I risked my life for these people. Gave everything for them.:<TAP>
\n\nAnd I'm more proud of that fact than anything else.:<TAP>
\nBut while I salute them, I doubt it will convey these\n<size=40>feelings</size> that well up within me.:<NONE>
When I open my eyes, a strange sensation lingers in my mind.:<style="Dash>
\nIt appears I have been dreaming.:<NONE>
In my dream, I was flying before I fell from the sky.:<TAP>
\nIt is the same dream I always have.:<NONE>
I hear dreams are what humans experience \nwhile undergoing memory reorganization.:<TAP>
\nBut if this is true, why do I have this dream?\nI have never flown; I have no memories of it.:
Maybe I only wish I could fly.:
\n\nOr maybe it's an influence from my older sister—the original.:<NONE>
I didn't dream today—or maybe I did and I just don't remember.:<TAP>
\nI hear that's possible as well, though you'd think I would know,\nconsidering that I'm dealing with my own body.:<NONE>
We constructs are not supposed to need sleep.:<TAP>

Not to say that we could perpetually act autonomously—
just that it was planned that we'd undergo regular
maintenance instead.:<NONE>
But I'm different. I'm the only one who sleeps. Who dreams.:<TAP>
\nI dream of memories that do not belong to me,\nmemories that intermingle with my own feelings.:<NONE>
I do not know why I am the only one to do so.:<TAP>
\nBut my dreams are indispensable to me.:<TAP>
\nI need them.:
I dreamed again today—or rather, I remember my dream.:<TAP>
\nI dreamed I met someone living in a small forest hut.:<NONE>
I concentrate on the sensations I felt while sleeping,\nand I am overcome by the sense I am unable to breathe.:<TAP>
\n\nThis memory most certainly belonged to my elder sister.:<NONE>
I cannot easily reach my elder sister's memories;\nit is like trying to navigate a path covered in fog.:<TAP>
\nPerhaps this is an effect of her losing control.:<NONE>
But my dreams are so far removed from reality.:<TAP>
\n\nAfter all, I have never seen a human before.:<NONE>
When I finally exit the facility and make my way outside,\nI find more lush nature—and ruined cities—\nthan in my memories.:<TAP>
\n\nAnd I also find hordes of machines.:<NONE>
But I see no humans anywhere. Not a single one.:<TAP>
\nThe sight is so different from my elder sister's\nmemories when she used to live on the surface.:<NONE>
How long have I been asleep? How long did I dream?:<TAP>
\nThere is no way for me to know the answer.:<NONE>
Will I ever reach the place from my sister's memory?:<TAP>
\n\nThe only clues I have come to me as I <size=40>dream</size>.:<NONE>
